TopicTitle: Congruent Triangles + KSP = Gaaah in Math Class

Articles.Content: So in Math we are currently dealing with congruent triangles, which means SSS SSA ASA a few others and SAS. Everytime I hear SAS in mathclass my brain goes instantly to KSP. Do I have a problem?

Welcome to the forums!

Note that in fact congruent triangles actually have a lot of use in orbital mechanics, as does geometry/trigonometry in general.

> 
> So in Math we are currently dealing with congruent triangles, which means SSS SSA ASA a few others and SAS. Everytime I hear SAS in mathclass my brain goes instantly to KSP. Do I have a problem?

Well hey, it's not like KSP goes away when you're not playing the game. 

This has happened to me too.
Actually, SSA isn't proof for triangle congruence. The third side can be anything, but it depends on the other two angles.

Oh, just wait until you learn circles and ellipses.

Welcome to the forum!
I learned about congruent triangles last semester, and yes, instead of Side-Angle-side I always thought of Stability Argumentation System instead...
Nope, it's a perfectly normal reaction. One of us! One of us!

> 
> Actually, SSA isn't proof for triangle congruence. The third side can be anything, but it depends on the other two angles.

There are at most two triangles defined by SSA if we restrict ourselves to Euclidean space.
Same thing happened for me but for Orbiter 2010. We were doing graphical transformations. Translation \*beep\* Rotation \*beep\*. That always made me think i was playing.
I live right next to a place called 'Jeb's mechanics' so I get mad when I go to school.

> 
> There are at most two triangles defined by SSA if we restrict ourselves to Euclidean space.

The closest thing to SSA is Hypotenuse-Leg. But that's in right triangles.

Maybe an equilateral triangle if you use the Law of Sines and you have the correct information. But that's the Law of Sines, not SSA per se. Law of Cosines might be applicable as well... Depending on what info you have.

But that's why it doesn't exist, it depends on exactly which info you have...
